description: Mac Management Basics is the first step in the Apple IT Pro certification path. Viewers who complete this exam will be awarded the Apple Certified Associate certification. The exam covers topics related to managing Macintosh networks and focuses on topics like deploying OS X, deploying software application, controlling machines with polices, and keeping systems up to date. It is an excellent starting point for anyone tasked with managing multiple Macintosh PCs.
name: ACA Mac Management Basics 10.11
subtitle: Apple Certificed Associate

episodes.description: Mac Management Basics is the first step in the Apple IT Pro certification path. Viewers who complete this exam will be awarded the Apple Certified Associate certification. The exam covers topics related to managing Macintosh networks and focuses on topics like deploying OS X, deploying software application, controlling machines with polices, and keeping systems up to date. It is an excellent starting point for anyone tasked with managing multiple Macintosh PCs.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:03.912
[SOUND] In this series,

2
00:00:03.912 --> 00:00:08.432
we're gonna be looking at

3
00:00:08.432 --> 00:00:12.753
Mac Management Basics.

4
00:00:12.753 --> 00:00:15.212
Don, can you tell us a little
bit about this certification?

5
00:00:15.212 --> 00:00:20.084
>> Sure, the Mac Management Basics exam,
it's designed to introduce

6
00:00:20.084 --> 00:00:24.410
people to the world of, well,
managing Macs, basically.

7
00:00:24.410 --> 00:00:27.060
[LAUGH] And so, it's kind of a neat one.

8
00:00:27.060 --> 00:00:29.670
It's part of Apple's training and
certification path.

9
00:00:29.670 --> 00:00:31.060
And they've got several certifications.

10
00:00:31.060 --> 00:00:32.963
Let me just bring it up
here on their webpage.

11
00:00:32.963 --> 00:00:36.040
The OS10 Training and
Certification Roadmap.

12
00:00:36.040 --> 00:00:38.910
They've got several, and it's gotten
a little confusing cuz some have been

13
00:00:38.910 --> 00:00:41.290
upgraded to El Capitan and some haven't.

14
00:00:41.290 --> 00:00:43.840
But basically you have these
two certifications that

15
00:00:43.840 --> 00:00:47.420
are Mac Integration Basics and
Mac Management Basics.

16
00:00:47.420 --> 00:00:49.588
There are two exams you can take.

17
00:00:49.588 --> 00:00:51.966
And when you pass either one of them,

18
00:00:51.966 --> 00:00:56.129
you get the Apple Certified
Associate Cerification, the ACA.

19
00:00:56.129 --> 00:01:00.079
And an Apple certified associate is
supposed to be some who's out there in

20
00:01:00.079 --> 00:01:04.490
the field, who's supporting Macs in
a business or education type environment.

21
00:01:04.490 --> 00:01:06.710
So the ACA certification
is that entry step,

22
00:01:06.710 --> 00:01:11.250
that first step on your journey to
getting certified in the Mac world.

23
00:01:11.250 --> 00:01:13.540
>> Now when it comes to
demographics on all exams,

24
00:01:13.540 --> 00:01:16.810
we have a certain body of
people that this is for,

25
00:01:16.810 --> 00:01:21.670
whether it be introductory,
whether it be advanced or intermediate.

26
00:01:21.670 --> 00:01:23.200
Don, what can we expect?

27
00:01:23.200 --> 00:01:25.340
>> This one is definitely beginner.

28
00:01:25.340 --> 00:01:28.620
So you don't have to know a whole heck
of a lot to be able to jump in and

29
00:01:28.620 --> 00:01:29.690
tackle this one.

30
00:01:29.690 --> 00:01:33.090
It's actually, I say it's one of
the easier certifications to get.

31
00:01:33.090 --> 00:01:34.550
It's not that it's super easy.

32
00:01:34.550 --> 00:01:37.754
It's just that it It's really
stuff you use everyday.

33
00:01:37.754 --> 00:01:42.290
Some certifications cover topics that
are such fringe knowledge that you're not

34
00:01:42.290 --> 00:01:43.580
gonna need.

35
00:01:43.580 --> 00:01:47.310
But this one, it's all practical stuff
that you are gonna use in the real world.

36
00:01:47.310 --> 00:01:48.560
I know I really enjoy this one,

37
00:01:48.560 --> 00:01:52.130
it's one you can find an easy tangible
way to apply in your workplace.

38
00:01:52.130 --> 00:01:53.730
So, you don't need
a tome of experience but

39
00:01:53.730 --> 00:01:55.490
you do need to be familiar with Mac OS.

40
00:01:55.490 --> 00:01:59.490
You do need to already know how
to get the system preferences and

41
00:01:59.490 --> 00:02:01.720
how to change basic operations,
things like that.

42
00:02:01.720 --> 00:02:03.180
Just really simple stuff.

43
00:02:03.180 --> 00:02:06.049
And then what we do is we basically
take those skills and we say,

44
00:02:06.049 --> 00:02:08.105
all right you know how
to do it on 1 computer,

45
00:02:08.105 --> 00:02:11.921
let's show you how to do it on 1,000
computers, and do it all at once, right?

46
00:02:11.921 --> 00:02:15.690
How to really manage these larger
environments that go beyond what a home

47
00:02:15.690 --> 00:02:17.010
user would make use of.

48
00:02:17.010 --> 00:02:19.990
So, if you've got a little bit of
exposure to the operating system,

49
00:02:19.990 --> 00:02:21.830
you'll do fine with the rest of it.

50
00:02:21.830 --> 00:02:24.910
>> As with any certification,
there are gonna be a series of topics and

51
00:02:24.910 --> 00:02:28.250
content that you're gonna have to be
aware of to be able to pass the exam.

52
00:02:28.250 --> 00:02:32.210
Don, what kinda topics can we expect
to see inside of Mac Management Basics?

53
00:02:32.210 --> 00:02:34.260
>> All right, well I've got a little
outline kinda fired up here.

54
00:02:34.260 --> 00:02:36.047
This is what we're gonna
build the show of.

55
00:02:36.047 --> 00:02:40.087
And basically it gets broken down into
six or seven different topics areas.

56
00:02:40.087 --> 00:02:42.380
We're gonna start with
creating system images.

57
00:02:42.380 --> 00:02:46.421
Most of us never have to install Mac OS
cuz it comes on our Macs when we buy them.

58
00:02:46.421 --> 00:02:50.399
But if you wanna have a standard image
on all of your machines in your entire

59
00:02:50.399 --> 00:02:53.110
company, you'll need to
create a system image.

60
00:02:53.110 --> 00:02:54.671
So we take a look at how to do that.

61
00:02:54.671 --> 00:02:58.767
And then we take a look at how to deploy
those images, so roll it out on hundreds,

62
00:02:58.767 --> 00:03:03.110
thousands, tens of thousands of computers
so you have a consistent environment for

63
00:03:03.110 --> 00:03:04.130
all of your users.

64
00:03:04.130 --> 00:03:06.550
Then we take a look at
managing those next.

65
00:03:06.550 --> 00:03:07.475
Once you've deployed them,

66
00:03:07.475 --> 00:03:09.590
how do you keep them nice and clean and
running the way that you want?

67
00:03:09.590 --> 00:03:11.997
How do you lock them down for
security purposes and

68
00:03:11.997 --> 00:03:14.680
just keep them configured
the way you want?

69
00:03:14.680 --> 00:03:17.140
We take a look at how to do
that with Apple Remote Desktop,

70
00:03:17.140 --> 00:03:19.370
which is really cool utility from Apple.

71
00:03:19.370 --> 00:03:22.940
And we also use the Profile Manager
which is another one.

72
00:03:22.940 --> 00:03:23.870
Two different tools.

73
00:03:23.870 --> 00:03:25.480
They perform a similar action but

74
00:03:25.480 --> 00:03:28.460
you'll see in the show there's
actually a difference between the two.

75
00:03:28.460 --> 00:03:31.327
Towards the end of the show we jump into
software updates cuz you've gotta keep

76
00:03:31.327 --> 00:03:32.421
your Macs up to date, right?

77
00:03:32.421 --> 00:03:35.925
Gotta keep them with the latest security
patches and application updates so

78
00:03:35.925 --> 00:03:36.754
they run smooth.

79
00:03:36.754 --> 00:03:38.815
And then we jump into the caching service,

80
00:03:38.815 --> 00:03:41.171
which helps us to save
bandwidth on the network.

81
00:03:41.171 --> 00:03:44.555
And we wrap up just talking a little bit
about the differences between those cuz

82
00:03:44.555 --> 00:03:46.000
you have to pick one or the other.

83
00:03:46.000 --> 00:03:46.797
You can't deploy both.

84
00:03:46.797 --> 00:03:49.726
So, those are some of the topics that
we're gonna be hitting throughout

85
00:03:49.726 --> 00:03:50.310
this series.

86
00:03:50.310 --> 00:03:53.110
And like I said,
every one of these are real world,

87
00:03:53.110 --> 00:03:56.780
practical skills that you will use in a
corporate environment where you use Macs.

88
00:03:56.780 --> 00:03:59.740
>> Now, you've done your studying,
you've watched the videos,

89
00:03:59.740 --> 00:04:01.330
you've gone out there and
you've researched.

90
00:04:01.330 --> 00:04:02.740
Now it's time to sit the seat.

91
00:04:02.740 --> 00:04:04.421
Don, how do I take this exam?

92
00:04:04.421 --> 00:04:05.023
>> All right, well,

93
00:04:05.023 --> 00:04:07.660
this exam's a little different than a lot
of the others that we do on ITProTV.

94
00:04:07.660 --> 00:04:12.110
Most of the time you've gotta go over
Pearson VUE's website or somewhere to take

95
00:04:12.110 --> 00:04:16.730
the exam, but for this one you can
take it online right from Apple.

96
00:04:16.730 --> 00:04:19.800
That's another reason that this one
is great to start out with because

97
00:04:19.800 --> 00:04:21.630
the content is good content.

98
00:04:21.630 --> 00:04:23.070
And it's real world stuff.

99
00:04:23.070 --> 00:04:24.610
It's not a ton of content.

100
00:04:24.610 --> 00:04:27.020
You can actually get used
to it pretty quick, and

101
00:04:27.020 --> 00:04:28.920
then the exam is inexpensive and
available online.

102
00:04:28.920 --> 00:04:31.310
So it's like a perfect storm of great
things to make this a wonderful

103
00:04:31.310 --> 00:04:32.340
cert to get.

104
00:04:32.340 --> 00:04:37.380
Now, as of the filming of this episode,
the 10.11 exam is not officially out.

105
00:04:37.380 --> 00:04:38.820
It's due out any day now.

106
00:04:38.820 --> 00:04:42.631
So for right now if you wanna take it,
you'll have to take the 10.10 exam, but

107
00:04:42.631 --> 00:04:45.420
the 10.10 and
10.11 exams are almost identical.

108
00:04:45.420 --> 00:04:49.962
There's very little difference
between Yosemite and El Capitan.

109
00:04:49.962 --> 00:04:52.540
In fact, the only real difference
is in the disk utility.

110
00:04:52.540 --> 00:04:54.260
The disk utility changed in El Capitan.

111
00:04:54.260 --> 00:04:56.650
Otherwise it's really about the same.

112
00:04:56.650 --> 00:05:01.512
So, if you go to Apple's website though,
you can browse to

113
00:05:01.512 --> 00:05:07.172
training.apple.com/itpro/macmanagement101-
0/exam.

114
00:05:07.172 --> 00:05:09.932
And be sure to check if the 1011/exam is

115
00:05:09.932 --> 00:05:14.600
available because by the time you
watch this it may very well be.

116
00:05:14.600 --> 00:05:17.850
Once you go to that site, here's where
it tells you all about the exam and

117
00:05:17.850 --> 00:05:19.320
how you can register for it.

118
00:05:19.320 --> 00:05:21.680
It is a two hour exam.

119
00:05:21.680 --> 00:05:22.800
It's taken online.

120
00:05:22.800 --> 00:05:24.440
You can take it from
the comfort of your own home.

121
00:05:24.440 --> 00:05:26.540
You don't have to go to an Apple center or
anything like that,

122
00:05:26.540 --> 00:05:28.220
you can just do it right
from your own computer.

123
00:05:28.220 --> 00:05:32.570
It costs $65.00, and you can take
the exam, and you'll get a pass or

124
00:05:32.570 --> 00:05:33.520
fail score right then.

125
00:05:33.520 --> 00:05:35.090
You'll know if you're certified.

126
00:05:35.090 --> 00:05:37.300
And now you're a Apple
certified associate.

127
00:05:37.300 --> 00:05:41.296
To take it you go to
training.apple.com/acrs.

128
00:05:41.296 --> 00:05:44.560
And on that website,
they'll have where you can register for

129
00:05:44.560 --> 00:05:47.087
the exam, take it,
pass it and get certified.

130
00:05:47.087 --> 00:05:50.587
So, like I said it's a great
place to get started.

131
00:05:50.587 --> 00:05:52.755
I shouldn't say it's an easy exam,
but I feel like saying that.

132
00:05:52.755 --> 00:05:55.195
You'll find that it's just
not a huge volume of content.

133
00:05:55.195 --> 00:05:56.905
So it's easier to grasp the material and

134
00:05:56.905 --> 00:05:58.485
it' something that you'll
make use of in real life.

135
00:05:58.485 --> 00:06:00.285
So, definitely one that I recommend.

136
00:06:00.285 --> 00:06:02.145
And one that I think really works out for

137
00:06:02.145 --> 00:06:05.635
the people that are wanting to get
started in the world of Mac management.

138
00:06:05.635 --> 00:06:08.235
So, if that sounds exciting to you
then you are in the right place.

139
00:06:08.235 --> 00:06:10.575
Stay tuned cuz we've got
Mac Management Basics for

140
00:06:10.575 --> 00:06:15.760
El Capitan OSX 10.11 coming up next.

141
00:06:15.760 --> 00:06:18.010
If that doesn't sound like
your cup of tea, don't worry.

142
00:06:18.010 --> 00:06:18.972
You're not hurting my feelings.

143
00:06:18.972 --> 00:06:21.290
You've got plenty of Linux and
Windows training available on the site.

144
00:06:21.290 --> 00:06:23.410
Be sure to check out our course library.

145
00:06:23.410 --> 00:06:26.000
But otherwise, enough of me rattling on.

146
00:06:26.000 --> 00:06:28.421
Let's get started with some
Mac Management Basics.

147
00:06:28.421 --> 00:06:35.089
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don introduce the image types that can be used to provision OS X El Capitan to machines. They explore system images like NetBoot, NetInstall, NetRestore and disk images like "dmg" files and the scenarios in which an administrator might use the different images as well as the utilities used to work with these image file types.
episodes.title: Installation Images

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don look at installation images. They talk about NetInstall and using the System Image utility. They will also dicuss how to customize setting using the Automater. They demonstrate the OS X utilities Disk Utility and System Image Utility.
episodes.title: Building NetInstall Images

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don explore building images with NetRestore. They demonstrate using a source computer running OS X El Capitan to create the NetRestore image as well as booting the source computer into Target mode to create the NetRestore image.
episodes.title: Building NetRestore Images

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don talk about how to deploy images to computers using removable media, specifically USB thumb drives. They also discuss the pro's and con's of using removable media to deploy and provision machine inside of a network.
episodes.title: Deploying via USB

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don dive into deployment of OS X El Capitan images to machines over the network. They will demonstrate how to setup and build the NetInstall server that will be used to deploy the operating systems to the devices inisde of the local area network as well as connecting the client machine to the server to obtain the EL Capitan OS image.
episodes.title: Deploying via Network

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don introduce Apple Remote Desktop (ARD). They look at using ARD to install software, updating software, reporting, automating tasks and reporting.
episodes.title: Apple Remote Desktop

topics.title: Managing Mac Computers with Apple Remote Desktop

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don take a look at policy-based management through Apple's One Directory. They talk about the benefits to using a directory such as Open Directory such as centralized user database management, centralized user account and password management. They explain the differences between and Open Directory Master server versus and Open Directory Replica server.
episodes.title: Open Directory

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don take a look at configuring and controlling setting to Apple devices through a powerful utility known as Profile Manager. They discuss the what is required to install and use the Profile Manager. They talk about the main components in Profile Manager like the Self-Service User Portal, Mobile Device Management (MDM) and the Web-based Administration Tool. They explore how the policies can be distributed through email, MDM or even user download.
episodes.title: Profile Manager

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don continue their discussion on the Profile Manager. They will demonstrate how to setup and configure users and groups. They walk through the process of creating a configuration profile as well as confirming that the profile is applied appropriately to the device. They also explain how to perform a removal of a device that is managed with a configuration profile.
episodes.title: Profile Manager Part 2

topics.title: Managing OS X Devices with Profile Manager

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don take a look at how to manage updates for not single machine but for hundreds or thousands of client machines through Apple's Software Update. They discuss Apple's recommended three phase best practice to deploying updates to clients. They demonstrate how to set up the Software Update server as well as configuring the client to recieve updates.
episodes.title: Managing Updates

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Don explore Caching Software Downloads. They will demonstrate how bring a Caching server online and discuss the types of content that can be cached like Apple Software Updates, iOS App Store Software, Mac App Store Software and iBooks Software. They will talk about how to verify the Caching server is setup and ready through inspecting the logs files and Data store for the Caching server.
episodes.title: Caching Downloads
